summary: This is a court filing from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, consisting of a letter to Judge Berman and a proposed order of nolle prosequi. It formally notifies the court of Jeffrey Epstein's death by suicide in custody on August 10, 2019, and requests the dismissal of the criminal indictment against him due to abatement.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased defendant in the criminal case. The document states he died by hanging (suicide) on August 10, 2019, while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, prior to trial.

persons.name: Richard M. Berman
persons.context: The presiding judge in the case (19 Cr. 490 (RMB)). The letter is addressed to him, and he is the one who must approve the order of nolle prosequi.

persons.name: Alison Moe
persons.context: One of the Assistant U.S. Attorneys who signed the letter and the proposed nolle prosequi order on behalf of the government.

events.title: Indictment Returned
events.description: An indictment was returned charging Jeffrey Epstein with one count of conspiracy to commit sex trafficking of minors and one count of sex trafficking of minors.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner later identified the cause as hanging and the manner as suicide.

events.title: Medical Examiner's Statement
events.description: The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner of the City of New York issued a statement officially identifying Epstein's cause and manner of death.

events.title: Filing of Nolle Prosequi Request
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office filed a letter and proposed order requesting the court dismiss the indictment against Epstein due to his death, citing the legal rule of abatement.

locations: United States Courthouse, 500 Pearl Street, New York, New York
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died on August 10, 2019, while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.
The New York City Chief Medical Examiner ruled the cause of death as hanging and the manner as suicide.
The U.S. Attorney's Office formally moved to dismiss the indictment (for conspiracy and sex trafficking of minors) due to Epstein's death, citing the legal doctrine of abatement.
The document states the government's commitment to stand up for victims who had come forward and those who had not.
The filing includes a direct reference to the government's obligations under the Crime Victims' Rights Act regarding victim notification.
